Nah this is misleading like you try to explain it with the cat thing but it's really simpler than that lol. With the reaction wheels, it's just that, they spin the wheel one way and the telescope reacts and spins the other way. Upon the amount of rotation being achieved then they reverse the spin and both the ship and the wheel come to a stop. It's different from a cat I think because the cat is all one structure whereas on the ship, the reaction wheel could be sped up and the ship could soon as long as you want along a given axis with no extra input until you want to stop. On the cat, it can only twist so far before it then needs to reverse the part it was USING to twist off from to bring the whole body of the cat in line with the angle. The ship is a rigid body though, and all rotates at once.

I did learn something. About the "locked in time" thing. 

I learned that even though we are building cutting edge technology, we need to be even more future oriented than we already are and that we should be thinking about how to build things that can be easily upgraded, perhaps without the object ever being touched by human hands.

In this way, old technology can keep up with new technology, atleast for a little while.

As an example, we can look at FPGA (Field Programmable Gate Array). An FPGA is basically a microprocessor in which the logic is configurable by software. What I mean is that the logic on the chip can be changed by altering the code in the bootloader (on an FPGA the chip will always default to how it left the factory, so loading the chip configuration is always the first thing that must happen). This would allow you (to an extent of course) to change the microprocessors in your system, as better ways to do things are found.

Obviously this implies building something like a space telescope with the most generic control devices possible. In other words, systems should be designed so that they can be easily changed by software only throughout a large range of operational needs.

What I think is happening with the 3 gyroscopes in space is that, while the system is balanced (all 3 gyros in sync), there is no rotation. Say we slow down the gyro on the x-axis...that reduces the energy (momentum) in that axis. Due to Conservation of Energy, the other two gyros make up the balance of energy lost in the x-axis by rotating the system in that direction. Once the desired rotation is met, then the gyro's are brought back in-sync and the system is balanced and motionless.
